material.mattext: Please remember the introductory definition of a computing device. Which of the following isÂ not an essential feature of a computing device?
Facility for displaying the process of computing.
A mechanism to reveal the result of a computation.
Hardware for processing a program.
The program itself.

item.title: Inferring from solution space to problem space

presentation.label: Inferring from solution space to problem space

material.mattext: Which of the following best describes what the algorithm does?
It shifts all bits one position to the left. The most significant bit falls out to the left.
It converts a signed integer represented by the bits to an unsigned integer.
It converts a large Unicode character into a small Unicode character.
It calculates the square root of the unsigned integer represented by the bits.
Which of the following statements about a Turing machine is true?
A Turing machine can compute any computable function.
A Turing machine requires either infinite memory or infinite time, but not both.
Every modern computer is a perfect instance of a Turing machine.
Turing-completeness is not a mandatory feature of a Turing machine.
Which of the following statements about this program fragment is true?

Line 6 could be syntactically correctly rewritten as

cin

>>
weight
;
The program fragment is wrong because the variableweightis not initialized.
There is no compound statement in the program fragment.
The program fragment contains exactly one empty statement.
Which statement about this program is wrong?
The program does not contain a sequence.
The program does not take any input.
The program does not produce any output.
The variablefactorial5is correctly declared and initialized.

You need to output the string

Insert newline with â\nâ and backslash with â\\â.

Which statement does this correctly?
cout << "Insert newline with \"\\n\" and backslash with \"\\\\\"." <<Â endl;
cout << "Insert newline with "\\n"\ and backslash with "\\\"\." << endl;
cout << "Insert newline with \"\\n\" and backslash with \"\\\"." << endl;
cout << "Insert newline with \'\\n\' and backslash with \'\\\\\'." <<Â endl;

Which statement correctly classifies people in minors (younger than 18) and adults (18 orÂ older)?
The variable age is of type int and contains the age of a person, the variable minor is of typeÂ bool; it is true for minors and false for adults.

if (18 > age)
{
  minor = true;
}
else
{
  minor = false;
}

if (age >= 18)
{
  minor = false;
}
{
  minor = true;
}

if (18 > age)
{
  minor = false;
}
else
{
  minor = true;
}

if (18 >= age)
{
Â  minor = true;
}
else
{
  minor = false;
}

It compiles without errors, but crashes at runtime. You suspect thatsomeFunc()is causing theÂ problem, but the debugger does not display or execute line 6,#include "MACRO.CPP". WhichÂ of the following is most likely true about the problem?

The line contains an include directive that is processed by the C preprocessor.
Therefore, itÂ is not displayed during debugging.
Probably the reason is that MACRO.CPP file does not exist.
The function does not return a value, which is probably the cause of the problem.
The last line contains a superfluous semicolon; this may be the source of the error.
Which of the following statements is true?
Executingcout << i << endl;immediately after will output 2.
Adding boolean values is not allowed.
Executingcout << i << endl;immediately after will output true.
Executingcout << i << endl;immediately after will output 1.
Which code fragment defines a pointer and initializes it with the address of the previouslyÂ declared variable?
double d { 42.0 }; double * dp { &d };
int i; int ip* { &i };
double d { }; int * dp { &dp };
int i; int * ip; ip = i;
Which program fragment declares a reference to the previously declared variable?
bool p; bool & q { p };
int j; int k {&j };
int m; &int n { m };
double o; double & p { & o };
Which of the following code fragments declares a reference to a pointer?
char c { 32 }; char * d { &c }; char * & e { d };
double & d { 99 }; double * e { &d };
double * m; double && n { m };
int i; int & j { i }; int * k { & j };
Which of the following code-fragments defines a syntactically correct function?

int f3(int i, int j)
{
Â  Â return 0;
}

void f4()
{
Â  Â return 42;
}

double f1()
{
}

int f8(int I)
{
Â  Â return;
}
Which of the following statements about this function definition is true?
The[[nodiscard]]attribute should be removed because the function returns nothing.
Thereturn-statement is necessary to terminate the function.
The function must be called at least once in a program.
The function produces unwanted side effects.
Which of the following statements about this program fragment is true?
After executing this program fragment,ppoints to a dynamically created integerÂ object.
Small objects are always created on the stack; therefore the stack contains anÂ anonymous integer object after the statement is executed.
The pointerpis initialized with the address 42; whatever memory location this valueÂ refers to.
When creating a dynamic object, it cannot be initialized the same time.
Which of the following statements about this program fragment is true?
After its execution,p,*q, andrall refer to the same object.
After its executionris a so-called âdangling referenceâ.
It is not allowed to refer to one and the same object more than twice.
After its execution the value ofris not defined.
Which of the following statements about this fact is true?

The function could be rewritten as:

bool isEven(int i);
// Other code including main()
// After main
bool isEven(int i)
{
   if (i % 2 == 0)
   {
      return true;
   }
   return false;
}
The program contains only a definition ofisEven().
The program contains only a declaration ofisEven().

The function must be rewritten as:

bool isEven(int i)
{
   if (i % 2 == 0)
   {
      return true;
   }
   else
   {
      return false;
   }
}
Which function declaration returns nothing and accepts one integer parameter passed by valueÂ andÂ two integer parameters passed by reference?
void computeHalves(int value, int &firstHalf, int &secondHalf);
int splitHalves(int& n, int lowerHalf, int upperHalf);
int computeHalves(const int value, int firstHalf, int secondHalf);
void splitHalves(int n, const int& lowerHalf, const int& upperHalf);
Which call of this function is illegal?
f(2,"s");
f(true,true,true,true);
According to German law, you must manage the genders male, female, and diverse in a C++Â program. Which of the following language elements is best suited for this purpose?
Enumeration type Gender with enumeration constants male, female, and diverse.

Three integer constants with different values for each gender, e.g.

const int male {Â 1 }; const int female { 2 }; const int diverse { 3 };

Three constants of type C-string with corresponding values, i.e.

const char * male {"male" }, * female { "female" }, * divers { "diverse" };

Three empty structs with corresponding names, i.e.

struct Male { }; structÂ Female { }; struct Diverse { };
